context:
<Summary source="https://www.cnn.com/2024/11/15/us/laken-riley-murder-trial">
# Summary of CNN Article on Laken Riley Case

**Date of Article:** November 15, 2024

## Key Facts and Details:

**The Victim and Incident:**
- Laken Riley was a 22-year-old nursing student at Augusta University's Athens campus
- She was killed on February 22, 2024, while jogging in a wooded area on the University of Georgia campus
- Riley went for a morning jog that morning and did not return

**The Defendant:**
- Jose Antonio Ibarra, 26-year-old undocumented migrant from Venezuela
- Prosecutors allege he "went hunting for females on the University of Georgia's campus"
- Charged with 10 counts including: malice murder, three counts of felony murder, kidnapping with bodily injury, aggravated assault with intent to rape, aggravated battery, obstructing an emergency call, tampering with evidence, and peeping Tom

**Smart Watch Evidence:**
- Riley placed a 911 call at 9:11 a.m.
- Her heart stopped at 9:28 a.m., with no more movement from her watch
- Prosecutor Sheila Ross stated the smartwatch data will show the encounter "was long" and "fierce"

**Physical Evidence (according to prosecution):**
- Riley was struck in the head with a rock multiple times and asphyxiated
- Ibarra's DNA was allegedly found under one of Riley's fingernails
- Ibarra's left thumbprint allegedly found on Riley's iPhone
- Three black disposable kitchen gloves found in bushes near Ibarra's home; one had blood on it that was determined to belong to Riley
- The glove with Riley's blood had a hole where the thumb would be
- A jacket recovered from a nearby dumpster had both Riley's and Ibarra's DNA/blood on it
- Riley's shirt was pulled up when her body was found, approximately 50 feet from the trail
- Crime scene showed significant disturbance with leaves covering most of the area except one large spot

**Trial Details:**
- Trial began in November 2024, nine months after Riley's death
- Ibarra waived his right to a jury trial; Superior Court Judge H. Patrick Haggard will decide the case (bench trial)
- Prosecutors seek life in prison without parole if convicted (not seeking death penalty, reason unclear)
- Defense attorney Dustin Kirby argues evidence is circumstantial and questions DNA methods and fingerprint evidence

**Defendant's Immigration History:**
- Arrested in 2022 after entering the US illegally, was "paroled and released for further processing" according to ICE
- ICE claimed he was arrested by New York City police in September 2023 for "acting in a manner to injure a child less than 17 and a motor vehicle license violation"
- However, NYPD stated they have no record of his arrest
- By February 2024, Ibarra was living in Athens, Georgia
- Arrested the day after Riley's death
- No evidence that Ibarra and Riley knew each other; police described killing as a "crime of opportunity"

**Political Context:**
- The case became "a lightning rod over crime and illegal immigration"
- Both Republicans and Democrats invoked Riley's story at political events
- Immigrant communities in Athens divided over the vitriol surrounding the case
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://abcnews.go.com/US/laken-riley-case-murder-trial-texts/story?id=116009547">
# Summary of Article: Timeline of Laken Riley's Last Moments During Trial

## Key Facts and Timeline:

**Victim and Case Details:**
- Laken Riley, 22-year-old Augusta University nursing student
- Found dead in wooded area on University of Georgia's Athens campus on Feb. 22 [no year specified in article]
- Jose Ibarra, 26, charged with malice murder and felony murder
- Ibarra was an undocumented migrant; case became rallying cry for immigration reform among conservatives, including President-elect Donald Trump
- Ibarra waived right to jury trial; case assigned to Superior Court Judge Patrick Haggard
- On Wednesday, Ibarra was found guilty of all charges and sentenced to life in prison without possibility of parole

**Timeline of Riley's Last Morning:**
- 8:55 a.m.: Riley texted her mother "Good morning, about to go for a run if you're free to talk"
- 9:03 a.m.: Riley called her mother, then started listening to music
- 9:05 a.m.: Captured on trail camera running with iPhone in left hand
- 9:06 a.m.: Runs out of camera view
- 9:11 a.m.: Called 911 via SOS application; dispatcher couldn't speak with anyone before call hung up
- 9:24 a.m.: Mother's call went unanswered
- 9:28 a.m.: Data from Garmin watch showed her heart stopped
- 9:38 a.m. - 11:47 a.m.: Multiple unanswered calls and texts from family
- 12:05 p.m.: Roommates reported her missing
- 12:38 p.m.: University of Georgia police officer found her body 65 feet off trail

**Forensic Evidence:**
- **Cause of death:** Combined effects of blunt force head trauma and asphyxia (Dr. Michelle Di Marco, autopsy)
- Eight injuries to left side of skull, one injury above right temple; one injury significant enough to cause brain bleeding and could have been fatal
- Evidence of asphyxiation, though method couldn't be categorized

**DNA and Physical Evidence:**
- Ibarra's DNA found under Riley's right fingernails; probability of belonging to anyone else: 1 in 10 billion (Ashley Hinkle, GBI crime lab scientist)
- Ibarra interviewed Feb. 23 with multiple scratches on his arms
- Riley's DNA found on bloodied jacket discarded by Ibarra near his apartment at 9:44 a.m. on Feb. 22
- Hairs on jacket originated from Riley or "someone with hair possessing the same distinct characteristics" (Anne Kisler-Rao, GBI crime lab)
- Riley's DNA on disposable gloves; probability of not being her: 1 in 500 octillion
- Gloves matched ones from drawer in Ibarra's apartment (though defense noted they could have come from different sources)
- Trail camera captured man heading toward intramural fields before 8 a.m. wearing clothes similar to Ibarra's Snapchat selfie from that morning (black Adidas cap)

**Defense Strategy:**
- Attempted to discredit DNA testing methods, including relatively new "True Allele" method
- Questioned statistical probability variations
- Ibarra waived right to testify
- Defense witness Stephanie Slaton testified that Diego Ibarra (Jose's brother) threatened her the night of Riley's murder, saying he would claim she did it and kill her if she told police anything
- Diego Ibarra was set to testify but his attorney planned to advise against it due to pending sentencing on federal charges (possessing fraudulent green card; faces maximum 10 years)

**Note:** Prosecutors stated Riley "refused to be his rape victim."
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/c23829939rjo">
# Summary of Article: Laken Riley Case - Jose Ibarra Sentenced to Life in Prison

**Date of Article:** November 20, 2024

## Key Facts:

1. **Verdict and Sentence:** Jose Antonio Ibarra, an undocumented Venezuelan immigrant, was found guilty of murdering 22-year-old nursing student Laken Riley and sentenced to life in prison without possibility of parole.

2. **Crime Details:**
   - Riley was killed on February 22, 2024
   - She was found dead in a wooded area of the University of Georgia (UGA) campus after not returning from her morning run
   - Prosecutors argued Ibarra went "hunting for females" on campus and "bashed her skull in with a rock"
   - Ibarra was arrested one day after Riley's death

3. **Trial Information:**
   - Ibarra was found guilty of all 10 counts, including felony murder, kidnapping with bodily injury, and aggravated assault with intent to rape
   - He waived his right to a jury trial; case was decided by county Judge H Patrick Haggard
   - Trial began the previous Friday (approximately November 15, 2024)

4. **Evidence:**
   - Smartwatch data showed Riley called police at 9:11 AM and her heart stopped at 9:28 AM
   - Ibarra's DNA was found under Riley's nails, indicating a struggle
   - Defense argued evidence was "circumstantial"

5. **Immigration Status:**
   - Ibarra entered the US illegally on September 8, 2022
   - Was released for further processing by ICE
   - Arrested in New York City in September 2023 for "acting in a manner to injure a child less than 17 and a motor vehicle license violation"
   - Was released by NYPD

6. **Political Context:**
   - The case became a flashpoint in the 2024 presidential election
   - President Joe Biden was heckled over the murder during his March State of the Union address
   - President-elect Donald Trump frequently invoked Riley's name on the campaign trail
   - Trump reacted to the verdict on Truth Social, stating it's "time to secure our border"

7. **Statistical Context:**
   - A National Institute of Justice study suggests undocumented migrants in the US are arrested for violent and drug crimes at less than half the rate of native-born citizens
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.onlineathens.com/story/news/courts/2026/02/02/judge-in-athens-hears-motion-for-man-convicted-of-killing-laken-riley/88464687007/">
# Summary of Article: Judge in Athens hears motion for new trial in Laken Riley case

## Key Facts and Developments:

**Current Legal Proceedings:**
- Western Circuit Superior Court Judge Patrick Haggard has set a **March 2 deadline** for lawyers to file briefs regarding a motion for a new trial for Jose Ibarra
- Defense attorneys David Douds and James K. Luttrell requested the new trial
- Special state's prosecutor Shelia Ross is opposing the motion

**Background on the Case:**
- Jose Ibarra, an undocumented immigrant from Venezuela, was convicted of murdering nursing student Laken Riley on the University of Georgia campus in 2024
- Riley was killed on **February 22, 2024** while running at a recreational complex near Lake Herrick
- Ibarra was convicted of murder and all other charges in a bench trial (trial before a judge without a jury)
- Judge Haggard found him guilty and sentenced him to **life in prison without the possibility of parole**
- Riley was a nursing student at an Athens campus of Augusta University and had previously attended UGA

**Defense Arguments for New Trial:**
- One issue raised was a motion claiming Ibarra has a congenital deficiency that would prevent him from helping lawyers prepare his defense
- DNA evidence was challenged by the defense
- The defense hired Ruth Ballard, a DNA expert retired from California State University in Sacramento, through the Georgia Public Defenders Council to review DNA testing conducted by the Georgia State Crime Lab

**Court Rulings:**
- A competency test was ordered and completed
- Judge Haggard ruled that Ibarra was mentally competent both at the time of trial and at the time of the crime
- The 15-page competency document was admitted into the case file but ordered sealed

**Security Measures:**
- When Ibarra was returned to court last week, he appeared under heavy guard including Clarke County Sheriff's deputies, federal officers, and two guards stationed on each side of him at the defense table
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.foxnews.com/us/laken-riley-murder-illegal-immigrant-suspects-trial-begins-last-minute-legal-maneuver">
# Summary of Article: Laken Riley Murder Trial Coverage

**Source:** Fox News  
**Date:** November 15, 2024

## Key Facts and Timeline:

**The Incident (February 22, 2024):**
- Laken Riley, a 22-year-old Augusta University nursing student, was allegedly murdered while jogging on University of Georgia campus trails near Lake Herrick
- Riley left for her morning run at 9:03 a.m.
- At 9:11 a.m., Riley called 911; the call was answered but there was no verbal response from Riley (only birds chirping and quiet noise)
- At 11:31 a.m., roommates began searching for her after she didn't return
- At 11:46 a.m., roommates found one of Riley's AirPods on the ground using "Find My Friends" iPhone app
- Shortly after noon, roommates reported her missing to UGA campus police
- At 12:37 p.m., UGA PD Sgt. Kenneth Maxwell found Riley unconscious, not breathing, partially naked, and covered in leaves approximately 50 feet from the main running trail
- Riley had severe injuries to the side of her head; investigators believe her body was moved after death

**The Suspect:**
- Jose Ibarra, 26-year-old illegal immigrant from Venezuela
- Lived in an apartment building less than half a mile from the crime scene with his brothers (also in the U.S. illegally)
- Charged with 10 counts total: one count of malice murder, three counts of felony murder, one count of kidnapping, one count of aggravated assault with intent to rape, one count of aggravated battery, one count of hindering a 911 call, one count of tampering with evidence, and one count of being a "peeping Tom"
- Pleaded not guilty to all counts

**Trial Details (November 15, 2024):**
- Trial began at 9 a.m. in Athens-Clarke County courtroom
- Judge Patrick Haggard granted Ibarra's request for a bench trial (no jury)
- Approximately 20 Riley family members attended

**Prosecution's Case (Prosecutor Sheila Ross):**
- Opening statement: "On Feb. 22, Jose Ibarra put on a black hat, a hoodie-style jacket, and some black kitchen-style disposable gloves, and he went hunting for females on the University of Georgia campus"
- "When Laken Riley refused to be his rape victim, he bashed her head in with a rock repeatedly"
- UGA Police Chief Jeffrey Clark described it as a "crime of opportunity"

**Defense's Position (Attorney Dustin Kirby):**
- Argued evidence would not prove beyond reasonable doubt that Ibarra killed Riley
- Described prosecution's case as based on "circumstantial evidence" requiring "gymnastics" to argue guilt
- Requested bench trial "with the hope and trust that despite the nature of this evidence that you could come to a verdict that was not just a way of easing this family's suffering, but it was based on an impartial and honest assessment of the evidence"

**Physical Evidence:**
- Around 10 p.m. on Feb. 22, Officer Zachary Davis found a dark sweatshirt in a dumpster near Ibarra's apartment complex with hair and blood on it; submitted to lab for testing
- GBI Special Agent Daniella Stuart photographed crime scene showing blood stains and hair on a rock near where Riley's body was discovered
- A latent fingerprint was observed on the bottom of Riley's iPhone near the hang-up area
- Apartment doorbell camera near the dumpster captured footage around 9:40 a.m. on Feb. 22 (article cuts off before completing this detail)

**Note:** The article appears to be cut off at the end during discussion of doorbell camera footage.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory/judge-hear-arguments-man-convicted-killing-laken-riley-129692881">
# Summary of Article: "Judge to hear arguments as the man convicted of killing Laken Riley seeks a new trial"

**Source:** ABC News

## Key Facts:

1. **Court Hearing:** Jose Ibarra, convicted of killing nursing student Laken Riley, is set to appear in court Friday (date of article publication) for arguments on his request for a new trial.

2. **Conviction Details:** Ibarra was convicted in November 2024 of murder and other crimes related to Riley's death, which occurred nine months earlier (February 22, 2024).

3. **Defendant Background:** Ibarra, 28, is Venezuelan and had entered the U.S. illegally in 2022. He was allowed to stay while pursuing his immigration case.

4. **Victim Details:** Laken Riley was a 22-year-old student at Augusta University College of Nursing. Prosecutors said Ibarra encountered Riley while she was running on the University of Georgia campus in Athens on February 22, 2024, and killed her during a struggle.

5. **Political Impact:** Riley's killing heightened tensions in the national debate over immigration. The first bill President Donald Trump signed upon taking office last year was the Laken Riley Act, inspired by her killing. The Act requires detention of people in the country without authorization who are accused of theft and violent crimes.

6. **Legal Arguments for New Trial:**
   - Defense lawyers argue constitutional rights were violated by the judge's denial of a request for delay so defense could have an expert review key evidence
   - Defense also argues constitutional rights were violated by admission of cellphone evidence they sought to exclude

7. **Trial Process:** Judge H. Patrick Haggard heard and decided Ibarra's case after Ibarra waived his right to a jury trial. Ibarra received a life sentence.

8. **Legal Representation:** Ibarra's trial attorneys filed a motion for a new trial within weeks of his conviction. New lawyers have since taken over his case and filed an amended motion for a new trial earlier this month (relative to article date).

9. **Evidence Disputes:**
   - Before trial, defense sought to exclude evidence from search of two cellphones believed to belong to Ibarra, arguing search warrants lacked probable cause. Judge Haggard rejected these arguments.
   - Defense also asked to exclude evidence and expert testimony based on True Allele Casework software (used for DNA analysis). Defense expert requested six weeks to review data, leading to a request for trial delay, which the judge denied.
</Summary>

**Laken Riley's Convicted Killer Angling For Another Trial**
Jose Antonio Ibarra, a 26-year-old Venezuelan national, is seeking a new trial after being convicted on all 10 counts for the February 2024 murder of 22-year-old nursing student Laken Riley on the University of Georgia campus in Athens, Georgia. Ibarra, who was apprehended by federal immigration officials after entering the U.S. near El Paso, Texas, in September 2022, is serving a life sentence without parole. His legal team has requested a new trial, citing a mental evaluation suggesting he was not competent to stand trial and alleging procedural errors during the original proceedings. The motion was heard by Judge Patrick Haggard, who presided over the original case. Ibarra had previously been arrested in New York on September 14, 2023, on charges of injuring a minor and a motor vehicle violation, but was released before a detainer could be issued—though the NYPD claims it has no record of the arrest. Critics of the Biden administration’s immigration policies argue Ibarra should have been deported prior to the murder. The case galvanized conservative political discourse, contributing to the passage of the Laken Riley Act in November 2024, which mandates the detention of illegal aliens accused of burglary, theft, larceny, or shoplifting and allows states to sue the federal government over immigration enforcement failures. Media outlets were instructed not to show Ibarra entering or exiting the courtroom or appearing in restraints during the January 31, 2026, hearing.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 31, 2026 03:49 PM

**Judge hears testimony from DNA expert as man convicted of killing Laken Riley seeks new trial | CNN**
A judge in Clarke County Superior Court, Georgia, heard testimony from DNA expert Ruth Ballard on January 30, 2026, as part of a motion for a new trial filed by Jose Ibarra, a 28-year-old Venezuelan man convicted of murdering nursing student Laken Riley in February 2024. Ibarra’s attorneys had requested a delay to allow Ballard six weeks to review evidence, but Judge H. Patrick Haggard proceeded with the trial as scheduled. Ballard testified that she could not rule out the possibility that Ibarra’s DNA was transferred to the jacket and other evidence indirectly, and acknowledged she had not completed a full review of the case. She also stated that a 'reasonable explanation' for the crime lab findings was that Ibarra’s DNA was deposited during the murder. Ibarra, who waived his right to a jury trial, was found guilty in November 2025 and sentenced to life in prison without parole. Prosecutors chose not to seek the death penalty. Ibarra’s defense argues that his constitutional rights were violated by the denial of a delay and the admission of cellphone evidence and DNA analysis using the TrueAllele Casework software. The defense had challenged the validity of the search warrants for two cellphones, claiming insufficient probable cause, and sought to exclude the evidence. Judge Haggard did not rule immediately on the motion for a new trial and gave attorneys one month to file additional legal arguments. The motion for a new trial, filed shortly after the conviction, has since been amended by new counsel. Under Georgia law, the filing of a motion for a new trial extends the deadline for filing an appeal beyond the 30-day window. The case has drawn national attention, particularly following the passage of the Laken Riley Act—signed by President Donald Trump in January 2025—which mandates detention for individuals in the U.S. without authorization who are accused of theft or violent crimes.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 30, 2026 09:20 PM
Source:[CNN](https://us.cnn.com/2026/01/30/us/laken-riley-dna-evidence-testimony)

**Judge hears testimony from DNA expert as man convicted of killing Laken Riley seeks new trial**
In Athens, Georgia, Clarke County Superior Court Judge H. Patrick Haggard heard testimony from DNA expert Ruth Ballard, retained by the defense, as part of a motion for a new trial filed by Jose Ibarra, a 28-year-old Venezuelan man convicted in November 2024 of murdering 22-year-old nursing student Laken Riley. Ibarra’s attorneys had requested a delay to allow Ballard six weeks to review evidence, but Judge Haggard proceeded with the trial as scheduled. During the hearing, Ballard stated she could not rule out indirect DNA transfer to a jacket and other evidence, though she acknowledged she had not completed a full review. Ibarra, who entered the U.S. illegally in 2022 and was permitted to remain pending his immigration case, was convicted of murder and other charges after encountering Riley on the University of Georgia campus on February 22, 2024. His defense argues that the denial of a delay to review key evidence and the admission of cellphone data—sought to be excluded—violated his constitutional rights. They are seeking to vacate his guilty verdict and life sentence and secure a new trial. The motion for a new trial, filed shortly after conviction and later amended by new attorneys, extends the appeal deadline under Georgia law, which requires a notice of appeal within 30 days of a final conviction or denial of a new trial motion. The judge had previously rejected defense requests to exclude evidence from two cellphones and testimony based on TrueAllele Casework software used in DNA analysis. The case has drawn national attention, influencing the passage of the Laken Riley Act, signed by President Donald Trump, which mandates detention of noncitizens accused of theft or violent crimes.

**Here's How Senator Warnock Described the Alex Pretti Vigil**
Senator Raphael Warnock traveled from Georgia to Minnesota and attended a vigil for Alex Pretti, an anti-ICE activist killed during a confrontation with Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) in Minneapolis. Warnock described the event in religious terms, stating, 'I felt like I was standing on holy ground' and that 'Alex Pretti's blood cries out to us. We are better than this.' While Warnock issued a statement expressing condolences for the death of Laken Riley, a separate victim of a violent crime, he did not publicly acknowledge the vigil for Riley held on February 26, 2024, and his delay in posting about her death drew criticism. Critics argue that Warnock’s reverence for Pretti and his stated intention to vote against a bill funding ICE reflect support for policies that opponents claim have contributed to the deaths of individuals like Riley. The article raises questions about whether Democrats will dismantle immigration enforcement or uphold the will of the American people, as expressed through the election of President Trump, who prioritized deportations. The article is published by Townhall on January 30, 2026.

**Jose Ibarra new trial motion hearing begins Friday nearly one year after the Laken Riley Act**
A hearing for Jose Ibarra's motion for a new trial began on Friday, January 30, 2026, nearly one year after the passage of the Laken Riley Act. Ibarra, convicted in November 2024 of murdering 22-year-old Laken Riley on the University of Georgia campus, filed for a new trial in December 2024. The hearing was held before Athens-Clarke County Superior Court Judge H. Patrick Haggard, who presided after Ibarra waived his right to a jury trial. Ibarra was found guilty on multiple charges, including felony murder, malice murder, kidnapping with bodily injury, aggravated assault with intent to rape, aggravated battery, hindering a 911 call, and tampering with evidence, and received multiple consecutive sentences, including life in prison without the possibility of parole. His defense argued that the conviction relied on circumstantial evidence and sought to exclude evidence from the search of two cellphones—claiming the warrants lacked probable cause—and requested a delay to allow a DNA expert to review evidence. Judge Haggard denied these motions and proceeded with the trial as scheduled. The trial occurs nearly one year after President Donald Trump signed the Laken Riley Act into law on January 20, 2025, the first law of his second presidential term, which mandates that local law enforcement and ICE detain undocumented immigrants who commit crimes involving bodily harm, assault on police, or shoplifting.

**Laken Riley's killer Jose Ibarra returns to court as illegal immigrant requests new trial in student's murder**
Jose Ibarra, who was convicted of murdering 22-year-old nursing student Laken Riley on February 22, 2024, on the University of Georgia campus, is seeking a new trial in Athens-Clarke County Superior Court, Georgia, on January 30, 2026. Ibarra, serving a life sentence without parole, is represented by post-conviction attorneys arguing that he was not competent to stand trial during the original proceedings. Judge Patrick Haggard, who presided over the original trial and sentenced Ibarra to life without parole, will hear the motion. The case gained national attention during Donald Trump’s 2024 presidential campaign, becoming a central issue in the immigration debate. Trump signed the 'Laken Riley Act' into law in 2025, requiring the detention of unauthorized immigrants accused of violent crimes or theft. Media outlets have been instructed not to broadcast or publish images of Ibarra entering or exiting the courtroom or appearing in shackles or handcuffs. Ibarra entered the U.S. illegally in 2022 and was allowed to remain while his immigration case was pending. Riley was a student at Augusta University’s College of Nursing, which has a campus in east Atlanta.

**Laken Riley Case Returns To Court As Killer Seeks New Trial**
Jose Ibarra, an illegal immigrant, was convicted in 2024 of murdering Georgia nursing student Laken Riley. On January 30, 2026, a judge, H. Patrick Haggard, began hearing oral arguments for a new trial based on claims that Ibarra suffers from a 'congenital deficiency' rendering him incapable of preparing a defense or knowingly waiving his right to a jury trial. The Laken Riley Act, signed into law by President Donald Trump in 2025, mandates federal detention of illegal immigrants charged with, arrested for, convicted of, or admitting to crimes such as burglary, theft, larceny, or shoplifting. Had the act been in place earlier, Ibarra would have been detained after a prior shoplifting citation. If the judge grants a new trial, Ibarra’s competency would be central; if found incompetent, he could be committed to a mental health facility for treatment. Discharge could occur if deemed non-dangerous. The judge is expected to rule within 90 days. The prospect of a retrial has stirred anguish among survivors and the victim’s family—Jessica Moore, a University of Georgia senior at the time, said, 'The feeling that loomed over our campus that day was one that students and the victim's family should never have to feel again.' CBS News reported that family members and others left the courtroom during graphic crime scene testimony, including body-cam footage of Riley’s body being discovered. Prosecutor Sheila Ross described Ibarra wearing a black hat, hoodie, and gloves, 'hunting for females' on campus, and brutally killing Riley after she resisted his assault. Trump referenced the case at a rally, claiming Riley 'would be alive today if Joe Biden had not willfully and maliciously eviscerated the borders of the United States.' Laken’s mother, Allyson Phillips, said, 'There's no end to the pain, suffering or loss. On that horrific day, my precious daughter was attacked, beaten, and shown no mercy.... This sick, twisted, evil coward showed no respect of Laken's life.'

**One year after Laken Riley Act, Angie Craig doesn't want to talk about her 'yes' vote | AlphaNews.org**
One year after the passage of the Laken Riley Act—a law mandating the detention of illegal migrants accused or charged with certain crimes, named after 22-year-old University of Georgia student Laken Riley, murdered by a Venezuelan national living illegally in the U.S.—Minnesota Democratic Representative Angie Craig is distancing herself from her initial 'yes' vote. When asked by the Daily Caller News Foundation whether she would vote differently today, Craig avoided a direct answer, instead asserting that the administration is not using the law and claiming it is being violated 'every law in the book.' She challenged critics to name a single instance where the law has been enforced. Craig’s shift has drawn criticism from within her party, including from Tim Walz’s deputy, Democratic Minnesota official Flanagan, who stated, 'Our immigrant neighbors deserve better.' Craig declined to define her political identity, saying she has always listened to constituents and will continue to do so. House Majority Whip Tom Emmer, the highest-ranking Minnesota Republican, accused Craig of a 'flip-flop' and labeled her shift as driven by 'Trump Derangement Syndrome,' claiming she has become 'far-left looney tunes' to outflank her Senate primary opponent. Republicans believe her divergence from her previously described 'centrist' stance, combined with internal party conflict between Craig and Flanagan, could weaken the Democratic nominee in the general election. Democrats must defend this seat, along with those in Georgia and Michigan, to have a realistic chance of regaining control in the November 2026 midterm elections.

**What Happened to Laken Riley? What to Know About the Nursing Student's Gruesome Murder (and the Controversial Immigration Law That Followed)**
Laken Riley, a 22-year-old nursing student at Augusta University, was murdered on February 22, 2024, during a morning jog on the University of Georgia campus. Her cell phone records show she called her mother at 9:03 a.m. and then made a 911 call that was abruptly disconnected. She was found dead with visible injuries, including blunt force trauma to the head, 65 feet off the trail in a wooded area behind a lake. Jose Ibarra, a Venezuelan man who entered the U.S. illegally in 2022 and had prior arrests for theft and driving without a license, was arrested the following day. Evidence included a blood-stained jacket found in a dumpster near the crime scene, Ibarra’s DNA under Riley’s fingernails, and physical injuries consistent with a struggle. Ibarra pleaded not guilty in May 2024 and was tried by a judge, who found him guilty on all charges—including malice murder, kidnapping, and concealing a death—on November 20, 2024, and sentenced him to life in prison without parole. Riley’s family, particularly her father Jason Riley, expressed grief and criticized the politicization of her death, stating she should be remembered for her character, not used as a political symbol. Her murder sparked national debate on immigration policy, leading to the passage of the Laken Riley Act in January 2025 by President Donald Trump, which mandates federal detention of undocumented immigrants accused of theft or violent crimes. Critics cite a 2024 National Institute of Justice study showing undocumented immigrants are arrested at less than half the rate of native-born citizens for violent crimes, questioning the law’s basis. Riley was described by peers, family, and community leaders as a kind, compassionate, and inspiring individual who lit up every room she entered.

**Trump Administration Overhauls H-1B Visa System, Ends Lottery, Cracks Down on Criminal Undocumented Immigrants**
The U.S. Department of Homeland Security announced on Tuesday, December 24, 2025, that it is revising the H-1B visa selection process to better protect American workers. The new policy will replace the current random lottery system with a preference for high-skilled, high-wage foreign workers, aiming to safeguard U.S. workers' wages, working conditions, and employment opportunities. The U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) stated that the existing lottery system has been exploited by American employers to hire foreign labor at wages below those paid to U.S. workers. Under the new rules, the annual H-1B cap will be set at 65,000 visas, with an additional 20,000 visas reserved for applicants holding advanced degrees from U.S. universities. The changes will take effect by the end of February 2026. In a separate enforcement action, Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) reported arresting 1,030 criminal undocumented immigrants over a 14-day period under the 'Laken Riley Act.' DHS Secretary Kristi Noem stated that the 'Angel's Honor Operation' was launched to honor Laken Riley, a Georgia nursing student murdered in February 2024 by a Venezuelan undocumented immigrant, and that President Trump has authorized the deportation of millions of violent criminal undocumented immigrants admitted under previous administrations. President Trump signed the Laken Riley Act in January 2025.

**Attorney representing man accused of killing girlfriend, hiding body in barrel, comments on immigration hold**
On December 16, 2025, in Harris County Criminal Courtroom, attorney Timothy Donahue represented Varela, the man accused of killing his girlfriend and hiding her body in a barrel, during a bond hearing. The bond request was denied. Donahue cited an immigration hold due to an ICE detainer and the federal Laken Riley Act, passed earlier in 2025, which limits the ability to release Varela from custody. He stated that, despite the circumstances, his focus remains on offering condolences to the family of the victim, Mr. Ramirez, while also asserting his intent to review the state’s full evidence file. Donahue noted that there has been a 'very courteous discussion' with the prosecution and that the defense is actively evaluating the case. The case remains under review, with proceedings ongoing under the constraints of federal immigration law.

**I'm a Celebrity 2025 confirms major rule change for Bushtucker trials - and it will impact viewers too**
ITV has announced a major rule change for the 25th season of I'm a Celebrity... Get Me Out of Here!, set to premiere on Sunday, 16th November 2025. The new rule prevents any contestant from being voted to perform a Bushtucker trial in consecutive days after being selected for two trials in a row. This change follows criticism of past seasons, such as Dean McCullough being voted for six trials in a row in 2024 and Matt Hancock facing the same fate in 2023. According to an ITV spokesperson, the adjustment ensures a fairer distribution of trial participation, allowing more campmates to 'shine' and giving viewers a broader opportunity to get to know the celebrities. The rule aims to increase audience engagement by diversifying the participants in the trials. This year’s cast includes Ruby Wax, Lisa Riley, Jack Osbourne, Martin Kemp, Kelly Brook, Eddie Kadi, Alex Scott, Angry Ginge (Morgan Burtwistle), Aitch, and Shona McGarty. The show will air on ITV1 and ITVX.

**I'm A Celebrity 2025 start date revealed as bosses make major change to the ITV show - Daily Record**
The 25th season of I'm A Celebrity...Get Me Out of Here! is set to premiere on November 16, 2025, according to the Mirror, following a Halloween-themed teaser trailer that indicated the show would begin in three weeks. **Hundreds gather to run in memory of murdered nursing student Laken Riley**
Hundreds of people gathered in Cherokee County on Saturday, October 25, 2025, for the second annual 5K run in memory of Laken Riley, a nursing student who was murdered while jogging on the University of Georgia campus in 2024. Jose Ibarra, a Venezuelan national in the country illegally, was convicted of her murder. The event, held at Hobgood Park, drew 806 participants who ran or walked to raise over $33,000 for the Laken Hope Foundation, which supports causes Riley cared about. Participants included individuals who knew her personally, such as 17-year-old Nathanael Sprivey, who ran on the same cross country team as Riley and knew her sister. Runner Nini Tran said the 5K helps keep Riley’s legacy alive. Last year’s event had over 700 runners and raised more than $30,000, with organizers anticipating a larger turnout next year.
